column51: Not associated with other Colletotrichum species complexes - pathogen of herbaceous crops (legumes, tomato, soybean). Infects leaves and seeds. ***Likely a hemibiotroph, but cannot find a specific paper confirming this.

column51: Causal agent of anthracnose disease in blueberry plants (Waller et al. 2018); has also been associated with diseases of many other horticultural and agricultural species. Also identified as an entomopathogen of scale insects (Marcelino et al. 2008).

column51: Causal agent of anthracnose in many angiosperm genera including Acer, Araucaria, Malus, Populus, Pyrus and especially Salix. Has also been isolated from gymnosperms species such as Araucaria excelsa (Norfolk Island pine - Damm et al., 2012). It does seem to have a preference for woody stems.

column51:
Major causal agent of Colletotrichum leaf disease in rubber trees. Also causes anthracnose disease in many other angiosperm species. Stunt anthracnose on celery caused by C. simmondsii. 
C. simmondsii behaves as a generalist invader on vegetative and generative parts of strawberry plants.  Member of the C. acutatum species complex (hemibiotrophic).

column51: Causal agent of Cytospora canker in hardwood trees. Considered to be a saprophytic species on dead bark that acts opportunistically as a parasite (Biggs and Davis 1982: Histopathology of cankers on Populus caused by Cytospora chrysosperma). Necrotrophic (Su et al. 2018: Poplar miR472a targeting NBS-LRRs is involved in effective defence against the necrotrophic fungus Cytospora chrysosperma). Also isolated as an endophyte from Populus tremula in northern Spain (Lupo et al. 2001: Endophytic fungi from flowers, capsules and seeds of Eucalyptus globulus).

column51: Soil-borne pathogen that causes crown root rot on tomato plants. Unlike F. oxysporum f. sp. lycopersici, radicis-lycopersici does not move through the vascular system of the stem (Menzies et al., 1990). ***Could not find any papers explicitly identifying F. oxysporum radicis-lycopersici as a hemibiotroph, but it behaves very similar to the other formae speciales as a pathogen, so it is very likely also a hemibiotroph.

column51: *** F. solani is a large species complex (FSSC) that displays a large diversity of lifestyles and pathogenicity among different isolates. FSSC 5 was isolated as a root endophyte from healthy Arabidopsis thaliana plants. Some species of this complex have been known to cause mycoses in humans. FSSC species also cause root rot, dieback, and wilt in bean plants (Souza et al., 2011). Difficult to classify the biological traits (host type, infected tissues) of this species as a whole when there is such variation.
column52:

column51: Member of the Fusarium solani species complex  - teleomorph of F. solani. Pathogenic to a range of plant species (many studies done on effects of N. haematococca on pea plants). Also occurs as a a dark septate root endophyte in many plants (Valli & Muthukumar, 2018). Seems to be defined as a hemibiotroph in the literature (Kahmann & Basse, 2001; Schmidt & Panstruga, 2011).

column51: Causal agent of apple canker - apple trees most often affected, but a wide range of broad-leaf species are affected as well. Infects host through leaf scars or wounds, and also infects fruit. Can have a latent period of 3-5 years before causing a systemic infection. Has also been isolated as an endophyte from beachgrass.

column51:
Mycoparasitic and nematophagous fungus (nematode parasite) - infects eggs. Used as a biocontrol agent against root knot and cyst nematodes. Can live as a root endophyte in plants, protecting them against nematodes and phytopathogenic fungi
 (https://onlinelibrary-wiley-com.ezproxy.library.ubc.ca/doi/full/10.1111/j.1744-7348.2009.00352.x). Can also live saprophytically in the soil in the absence of its hosts 
(https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3625126/). First draft genome sequence: https://www-sciencedirect-com.ezproxy.library.ubc.ca/science/article/pii/S1087184514000188

column51: Polyextremophilic yeast species that has been isolated from many harsh environments. Often isolated as an epiphyte or endophyte on a diversity of plants. Used as a biocontrol agent in agriculture because it produces many enzymes that exhibit antimicrobial activity.

column51: Originally isolated from marble in the Mediterranean basin - thought to be an important rock inhabiting microcolonial fungus. Able to adapt to extreme changes in environmental conditions. column51: General plant pathogen causing Leaf Fall Disease in a large range of host plants in tropical and subtropical regions (many fruit and ornamental species affected). column51: Causal agent of Citrus black spot (CBS) in Citrus spp. Infects fruit and leaves, but can also be present as a aymptomatic endophyte in Citrus tissues. Can also live saprobically on the dead/dying citrus leaves. ***Appears to be described as a necrotroph in the literature  (e.g. Rodrigues et al., 2019) - but this is slightly unclear. Other Phyllosticta species have been described as both necrotrophs and hemibiotrophs, but I cannot find any literature supporting these in the citrus tan spot pathogens.

column51: Pathogen of graminaceous species (causes leaf blotch) - closely related to Z. tritici. Isolated from grass species in northern Iran (not found on wheat though). Described as a hemibiotroph in MycoCosm, but some evidence suggests that Zymoseptoria species act more as latent necrotrophs (Sánchez-Vallet et al., 2015).

column51: Sexual state of the filamentous fungus Hormoconis resinae. Often found in marine environments and is known to grow on a variety of substrates. Is central to investigations on new biofuels due to its ability to produce hydrocarbons. Opportunistic saprophyte that has been found to infect American sole. (Lesions in the musculature of captive American plaice Hippoglossoides platessoides caused by the fungus Hormoconis resinae (Deuteromycetes): https://www.int-res.com/articles/dao/28/d028p107.pdf)

column51: Causal agent of scleroderris canker, or Brunchorstia disease, in conifer species - results in defoliation and stem cankers. Occurs globally as different races, which exhibit differences in distribution and pathogenicity. Classified as a necrotroph by Tapia 2015 and Adomas and Asiegbu 2006: Analysis of organ-specific responses of Pinus sylvestris to shoot (Gremmeniella abietina) and root (Heterobasidion annosum) pathogens). Has also been shown to survive as an endophyte.

column51: Considered one of the basal lineages of fungi, but unique in that it exhibits complex multicellularity instead of the typical yeast growth of basal fungi. column51: Anther smut fungus - hosts are members of the Caryophyllaceae. Fungal spores replace host pollen rendering the host plant sterile. Vegetative structures of the host are infected, but less affected than the reproductive structures. ***Microbotryum species thought to have a diphasic life cycle - alternates between saprotrophy and biotrophy, but JGI lists these species as obligate biotrophs...?

column51: Wood decay fungus specialized to oak species (Quercus). Identified as a parasite Baldrian (2004), but I cannot find any other literature that supports this claim. *** JGI states this species is a brown rot fungus (Nagy et al 2016), but another source identify it as a white rot (Baldrian 2004). Most sources seem to refer to it as a brown rot species so I will label it as such for now.

column51: Ganoderma sp. 10597 belongs to a genus of white-rot fungi - it is a North American isolate belonging to the Ganoderma lucidum species complex. ***Members of this genus can act as opportunistic plant pathogens (Binder et al. 2013; Kumari and Sirsi 1972; Paterson 2007), but cannot find confirmation that this specific strain acts as a pathogen.

Mostly attacks conifer species, but some deciduous species can also be affected - infects trees through wounds in the roots or stem (Asiegnu et al. 2005).

column51: Saprotrophic fungus that grows on decaying conifer wood. ***JGI states that it is thought to be a brown-rot species, but the genome reference paper classifies it as 'uncertain' (has both white-rot and brown-rot characteristics) (Riley et al. 2014) and it is identified as a white rot species elsewhere (Pellitier and Zak 2018).

column51: Hemibiotrophic fungal pathogen - causal agent of Witches' broom disease (WBD) in cacao. Spores infect aerial meristematic tissues including shoots, flowers, and developing pods (Meinhardt et al. 2008). Cycles between two life phases: biotrophy and necrotrophy/saprotrophy (Mondego et al. 2008) and has been shown to infect stems and leaves (Ceita et al. 2007).

column51: *** Typo in JGI name --> the species name should be encephala (with an 'a') - Also known as Tremella encephala (this was the species name that brought up more hits in the literature search - no literature was found when searching for Naematella encephela). Mycoparasite on the basidiomycete plant pathogen Stereum sanguinolentum. ***Grows saprotrophically in culture in the lab (yeast form) (Pippola and Kytoviita 2009 - Cryptogamie Mycologie 30(1): 3-19) but cannot find any literature confirming it acts as a saprotroph in nature.

column51: White-rot fungus isolated most often from hardwood species - one of the most well-studied white-rot species. Unique among white-rot fungi in that it appears to leave the cellulose of wood completely untouched. Also has a uniquely high optimum temperature (40ºC). (Kersten and Cullen 2007)

column51: Root endophyte that displays a biphasic lifestyle switching between endophytism and saprotrophy (similar to hemibiotrophs but without a clear necrotrophic disease-causing phase - P. indica is actually beneficial to its hosts) (Zuccaro et al 2011). Forms a mycorrhizal-like beneficial association with its host species but is distinct from mycorrhizal species in its growth.

column51: Soil-borne necrotrophic plant pathogen with a wide host range of Angiosperms- causal agent of seedling blight, root rot, hypocotyl rot, crown rot, stem rot, limb rot, pod rot, stem canker, black scurf, and damping-off (Foley et al. 2016; Ajayi‐Oyetunde and Bradley 2018). R. solani is a species complex. Can also grow saprotrophically in the soil (Bailey et al. 2000; Otten et al. 2004)

column51: White-rot wood decay fungus that can also act pathogenically as an opportunistic parasite in living trees by infecting through wounds - conifer and hardwood species (but predominantly in hardwoods) (Takemoto et al. 2010). Also acts as an opportunistic pathogen in humans causing sinusitus and other diseases (Premamalini et al. 2011; Rihs et al. 1996). ***Has also been shown to act as a mycoparasite (Tzean and Estey 1978), but this was only shown in this one study.

column2: Serpula himantioides (S.lacrymans var shastensis) MUCL38935 v1.0
column51: Brown-rot species complex - mostly colonizes coniferous wood, but also a bit problem in the building industry as it regular invades construction timber. ***Appears to act as a minor opportunistic pathogen: was reported to cause butt rot in Douglas fir and Japanese larch in Germany and Denmark (Seehann 1986; Koch and Thomsen 2003).  Serpula lacrymans is known as its sister species.

column51: Jelly fungus that is a mycoparasite of wood-decaying fungi (Peniophora spp.) (Zugmaier and Oberwinkler 1995; Lackner et al. 2012) - also known as witch's butter. ***JGI also classifies it as a white-rot fungus, but I cannot find any literature to support this (literature supports that it is a saprotroph, but not a white-rot).

column51: Yeast fungus that acts as an opportunistic pathogen in immunocompromised humans (causes trichosporonosis). Classified as a plant growth-promoting yeast by Nutaratat et al. (2014). Isolated as a beneficial root epiphyte from the rhizosphere of sugar beet (El-Tarabily 2004).
column52:
1. Yang, R., Ao, J., Wang, W., Song, K., Li, R., and Wang, D. (2003). Disseminated trichosporonosis in China. Mycoses 46, 519-523. Available at: http://doi.wiley.com/10.1046/j.1439-0507.2003.00920.x [Accessed July 3, 2019].
2. Nutaratat, P., Srisuk, N., Arunrattiyakorn, P., and Limtong, S. (2014). Plant growth-promoting traits of epiphytic and endophytic yeasts isolated from rice and sugar cane leaves in Thailand. Fungal Biol. 118, 683–694.
3. El-Tarabily, K.A. (2004). Suppression of Rhizoctonia solani diseases of sugar beet by antagonistic and plant growth-promoting yeasts. J. Appl. Microbiol. 96, 69–75.

column51: Oleaginous (oil-accumulating) yeast species often researched for its use in the biofuel industry. Originally isolated from cheese plant floors (Yaguchi et al. 2017). *** Difficult to find literature describing the natural habitat of this species and whether it is a pathogen like most of the other species in this genus.
